content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <feed xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2005/Atom">   <id>https://fosdem.org/</id>   <title>FOSDEM 2015</title>   <updated>2015-01-30T23:00:00Z</updated>   <link rel="alternate" href="https://fosdem.org/"/>   <link rel="self" href="https://fosdem.org/2015/atom.xml"/>   <author>     <name>FOSDEM team</name>     <uri>https://fosdem.org</uri>   </author>   <entry>     <id>tag:fosdem.org,2015-01-31:/2015/news/2015-01-31-need-volunteers/</id>     <title type="html">FOSDEM needs you!</title>     <published>2015-01-30T23:00:00Z</published>     <updated>2015-01-30T23:00:00Z</updated>     <link rel="alternate" href="https://fosdem.org/2015/news/2015-01-31-need-volunteers/"/>     <content type="html"><p>   We would really like some more volunteers, particularly for crowd control and   infodesk duty (selling t-shirts, being helpful, etc). </p>  <p>   If you have some spare energy, the FOSDEM team would really appreciate some   more volunteers to help out particularly with crowd control and selling   t-shirts at the infodesk. </p> <p>   Please report to the infodesk in the K building (ask for Koert!) to claim a   bright orange t-shirt and help us make FOSDEM even better! </p></content>     <summary type="html"><p>   We would really like some more volunteers, particularly for crowd control and   infodesk duty (selling t-shirts, being helpful, etc). </p> </summary>   </entry>   <entry>     <id>tag:fosdem.org,2015-01-31:/2015/news/2015-01-31-video-mostly-working/</id>     <title type="html">Recording and streaming mostly working!</title>     <published>2015-01-30T23:00:00Z</published>     <updated>2015-01-30T23:00:00Z</updated>     <link rel="alternate" href="https://fosdem.org/2015/news/2015-01-31-video-mostly-working/"/>     <content type="html"><p>   As pointed out during the opening talk, we have a completely new recording and   streaming workflow this year.  After some teething problems this morning,   we're happy to report that most things are now working! </p>  <p>   Unfortunately, we were not able to record or stream the opening presentation   and the first part of Karen Sandler's <em>Identity Crisis</em> keynote. </p> <p>   Our video team and network team are working hard to fix the remaining teething   problems and we hope to be able to have everything working smoothly in very   short order. </p> <p>   Keep an eye on <a href="https://live.fosdem.org/">https://live.fosdem.org/</a>   for streams!  Note that even if the streams are not working, presentations   <em>are</em> being recorded.  Recordings will be available very shortly after   (or possibly even during) the conference. </p> <p>   Please bear with us! </p></content>     <summary type="html"><p>   As pointed out during the opening talk, we have a completely new recording and   streaming workflow this year.  After some teething problems this morning,   we're happy to report that most things are now working! </p> </summary>   </entry>   <entry>     <id>tag:fosdem.org,2015-01-31:/2015/news/2015-01-31-ipv6-only-again/</id>     <title type="html">IPv6-only wireless network again!</title>     <published>2015-01-30T23:00:00Z</published>     <updated>2015-01-30T23:00:00Z</updated>     <link rel="alternate" href="https://fosdem.org/2015/news/2015-01-31-ipv6-only-again/"/>     <content type="html"><p>   Last year we turned off IPv4 on our main <code>FOSDEM</code> wireless network.   They idea is to confront developers with the IPv6-reality and encourage them   to fix bugs.  Progress has been made, but there is a lot of work left to do! </p>  <p>   FOSDEM is a unique opportunity to confront thousands of developers with an   IPv6-only reality. We are hopeful that making our default network IPv6-only   will encourage people to fix bugs in applications and devices. </p> <p>   The <code>FOSDEM</code> network has NAT64 and DNS64 transition measures in   place for communicating with the legacy internet. For those who need it, the   <code>FOSDEM-legacy</code> wireless network provides the same dual stack   connectivity we offered on <code>FOSDEM</code> prior to 2014. </p>  <p>   While last year we had "seatbelts" in place for flipping <code>FOSDEM</code>   back to dual stack, we decided not to implement those this year.  If the main   network catches fire, we will just have to fix our bugs! </p>  <ul><li><code>FOSDEM</code>: IPv6-only, provides NAT64 and DNS64. Recursive     DNS resolvers announced with RA and DHCPv6. If you need to configure DNS     manually, use 2001:67c:1810:f056::2 and 2001:41d0:2:1959:21c:c0ff:fe88:6f58</li>    <li><code>FOSDEM-legacy</code>: provides native IPv6 and legacy IP connectivity. No DNS64.</li> </ul></content>     <summary type="html"><p>   Last year we turned off IPv4 on our main <code>FOSDEM</code> wireless network.   They idea is to confront developers with the IPv6-reality and encourage them   to fix bugs.  Progress has been made, but there is a lot of work left to do! </p> </summary>   </entry>   <entry>     <id>tag:fosdem.org,2015-01-30:/2015/news/2015-01-30-bof-announce/</id>     <title type="html">BoF rooms and Announcement + Job corner</title>     <published>2015-01-29T23:00:00Z</published>     <updated>2015-01-29T23:00:00Z</updated>     <link rel="alternate" href="https://fosdem.org/2015/news/2015-01-30-bof-announce/"/>     <content type="html"><p>   Just like previous editions, we will have two freely bookable rooms for open source communities to use (BoF rooms), as well as an announcement corner and job corner. See below for the details. </p>   <hr /><h4>Announcement and job corner</h4> <p>   There will also be an announcement corner and a job corner again in the H building. Any announcement regarding open source software, communities or events around FOSDEM can be put there. At the job corner, you can put job offers assuming they involve open source software (no active flyering/recruiting allowed). </p>   <h4>BoF rooms</h4> <p>   The BoF room concept is simple: any project or community can reserve a timeslot   (fifteen minutes to an hour), during which they have the room just to   themselves. </p>  <p>   These rooms are intended for ad-hoc discussions, meet-ups or brainstorming   sessions. They are not a replacement for a developer room and they are   certainly not intended for talks. The rooms are deliberately not equipped   with projectors. The rooms are small and cosy. There are seats for   approximately thirty people. </p>  <p>   Reservations can be made only during the event and are on a first-come,   first-served basis. The signup sheets will be at the infodesk in the H   building, the rooms are in the same building (second floor). </p></content>     <summary type="html"><p>   Just like previous editions, we will have two freely bookable rooms for open source communities to use (BoF rooms), as well as an announcement corner and job corner. See below for the details. </p>  </summary>   </entry>   <entry>     <id>tag:fosdem.org,2015-01-28:/2015/news/2015-01-28-call-for-volunteers/</id>     <title type="html">Call for volunteers</title>     <published>2015-01-27T23:00:00Z</published>     <updated>2015-01-27T23:00:00Z</updated>     <link rel="alternate" href="https://fosdem.org/2015/news/2015-01-28-call-for-volunteers/"/>     <content type="html"><p>With FOSDEM just around the corner, it is time for us to enlist your help.</p>   <p>   Every year, an enthusiastic band of volunteers helps us make FOSDEM a fun and   safe place for all our attendees. We could not do this without you. This year   we again need as many hands as possible, especially during the buildup   (starting Friday at noon) and teardown (Sunday evening). No need to worry   about missing lunch. Food will be provided. </p>  <p>   If you have some spare time during the weekend and would like to be a part of   the team that makes FOSDEM tick: </p>  <p>We need help with the following:</p>  <ul><li>     Setting up the venue on Friday: this mostly involves carrying tables to     their destinations and setting them up, putting up signage, covering the     walls in brown paper, ... in short: transform the campus into a conference     venue. We need as many volunteers as possible for this task.   </li>   <li>     Deploying the network on Friday: rolling out, neatly securing and crimping     UTP cables. People with experience rolling out networks and crimping cables     are very welcome!   </li>   <li>     Manning the infodesk during the weekend: help out fellow attendees with     their questions, sell t-shirts, ... . Proficiency in English is a must, but     if you know other languages, it certainly wouldn't hurt.   </li>   <li>     Heralds: briefly introduce the speakers and the topics of their talks, make     sure all talks end on time by giving speakers cues near the end of their     time slot. Keep an eye out on room safety and report potential issues such     as overcrowded rooms before it becomes more than a "potential" issue.   </li>   <li>     Safety: keep an eye out for hazardous situations such as patches of ice that     could trip people up, overcrowded rooms, ... This also involves barring     entrance to rooms that are at full capacity so we can keep the conference     safe for everyone. This can be combined with moderation.   </li>   <li>     Teardown and cleanup on Sunday evening: collecting beer bottles, tearing     down the network, pulling brown paper off the walls, taking down the signage,     stacking the rental tables in neat heaps, broom the floors, ... Basically, make     sure we're welcome again next year. ;)   </li> </ul><p>   If any or all of these sound like your kind of gig, pick your task(s) at <a href="https://volunteers.fosdem.org">https://volunteers.fosdem.org</a> and subscribe to the   <a href="https://lists.fosdem.org/listinfo/volunteers">volunteers mailing list</a>. Feel free to shout out and introduce yourself! </p>  <p>   In addition to general volunteer work, we are also looking for volunteers   specifically to help out with video-related work. This involves: </p>  <ul><li>Operating a camera;</li>   <li>Regulating audio levels;</li> </ul><p>   While A/V experience is of course always welcome, all that's really needed is   that you're interested; on-the-job training will be provided. </p></content>     <summary type="html"><p>With FOSDEM just around the corner, it is time for us to enlist your help.</p>  </summary>   </entry>   <entry>     <id>tag:fosdem.org,2015-01-27:/2015/news/2015-01-27-last-set-of-speaker-interviews/</id>     <title type="html">Last set of FOSDEM 2015 speaker interviews</title>     <published>2015-01-26T23:00:00Z</published>     <updated>2015-01-26T23:00:00Z</updated>     <link rel="alternate" href="https://fosdem.org/2015/news/2015-01-27-last-set-of-speaker-interviews/"/>     <content type="html"><p>Our <a href="/2015/interviews/">collection of interviews</a> with the FOSDEM 2015 main track speakers is now complete.</p>   <p>We proudly present the last set of speaker interviews:</p>  <ul><li>David Chisnall: <a href="/2015/interviews/2015-david_chisnall/">The CHERI CPU. RISC in the age of risk</a></li>     <li>Holger Levsen: <a href="/2015/interviews/2015-holger-levsen/">Stretching out for trustworthy reproducible builds. The status of reproducing byte-for-byte identical binary packages from a given source</a></li>     <li>Jonathan Woodruff: <a href="/2015/interviews/2015-jonathan-woodruff/">BERI. An open RISC softcore for research and experimentation</a></li>     <li>Karen Sandler: <a href="/2015/interviews/2015-karen-sandler/">Identity Crisis: Are we who we say we are? </a></li>     <li>Lukas Berk: <a href="/2015/interviews/2015-lukas-berk/">Ubiquitous Performance Analysis and System Introspection. An introduction to Performance Co-Pilot and Systemtap</a></li>     <li>Ryan MacDonald: <a href="/2015/interviews/2015-ryan-macdonald/">Living on Mars: A Beginner's Guide. Can we Open Source a society?</a></li>     <li>Tom Van Baak: <a href="/2015/interviews/2015-tom-van-baak/">Precise time: from CPU clocks to hacking the Universe. Adventures of a time nut</a></li> </ul><p>See you at FOSDEM this weekend!</p></content>     <summary type="html"><p>Our <a href="page:interviews">collection of interviews</a> with the FOSDEM 2015 main track speakers is now complete.</p>  </summary>   </entry>   <entry>     <id>tag:fosdem.org,2015-01-23:/2015/news/2015-01-23-beerevent/</id>     <title type="html">Join your fellow hackers for a drink next Friday!</title>     <published>2015-01-22T23:00:00Z</published>     <updated>2015-01-22T23:00:00Z</updated>     <link rel="alternate" href="https://fosdem.org/2015/news/2015-01-23-beerevent/"/>     <content type="html"><p>   Looking for something to do the evening before FOSDEM? </p>   <p>   Like every year, many FOSDEM attendees are planning to enjoy some beers at the   <a href="http://www.deliriumcafe.be/">Delirium Caf\ufffd\ufffd</a>, in a beautiful   alley near the   <a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grand_Place">Grand Place</a>   in Brussels.   We have reserved most of the bar (most of the alley in fact!) again this year. </p>  <p>   Come and join us next Friday, 30 January, from 17:00(ish). </p>  <p>Read the <a href="/2015/beerevent/">beer event page</a> for all the details!</p>  <p>   If the beer event is very busy or if you would like dinner before heading over   (Delirium Caf\ufffd\ufffd does not serve food), a number of other events are on.  These   are just the ones we know about (check the <a href="https://lists.fosdem.org/mailman/listinfo/fosdem">fosdem@ mailing   list</a> for more announcements): </p>  <p>   So far:   </p><ul><li>The Software Freedom Conservancy is <a href="http://sfconservancy.org/news/2015/jan/20/supporter-night-2015/">organising    a dinner nearby</a> (tickets cheaper when <a href="http://sfconservancy.org/supporter/event.html">bought in advance</a>).     </li>   </ul><p>   Alternatively there are plenty of local restaurants within ten minutes walk of   the Delirium\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdyou can't miss them! </p>  <p>See you there!</p>  <p>PS: Drink wisely.  Belgian beers are stronger than you might be used to. <code>:-)</code></p></content>     <summary type="html"><p>   Looking for something to do the evening before FOSDEM? </p>  </summary>   </entry> tracks schedule is now   complete. </p> </summary>   </entry>   <entry>     <id>tag:fosdem.org,2015-01-21:/2015/news/2015-01-21-fourth-fosdem-2015-speaker-interviews/</id>     <title type="html">Fourth set of FOSDEM 2015 speaker interviews</title>     <published>2015-01-20T23:00:00Z</published>     <updated>2015-01-20T23:00:00Z</updated>     <link rel="alternate" href="https://fosdem.org/2015/news/2015-01-21-fourth-fosdem-2015-speaker-interviews/"/>     <content type="html"><p>We are pleased to announce a fourth round of interviews with some of our main track speakers:</p>   <ul><li>Alex Bradbury: <a href="/2015/interviews/2015-alex-bradbury/">lowRISC: The path to an open-source SoC</a></li>     <li>Federico Vaga and Matthieu Cattin: <a href="/2015/interviews/2015-federico-vaga/">A GPS watch made of free software and hardware</a></li>     <li>Harlan Stenn: <a href="/2015/interviews/2015-harlan-stenn/">NTF's General Timestamp API and Library: Current timestamps suck. We can do much better</a></li>     <li>Martin Burnicki: <a href="/2015/interviews/2015-martin-burnicki/">Technical Aspects of Leap Second Propagation and Evaluation</a></li>     <li>Pepijn Noltes: <a href="/2015/interviews/2015-pepijn-noltes/">Modularizing C software with Apache Celix</a></li>     <li>Steve Klabnik: <a href="/2015/interviews/2015-steve-klabnik/">The story of Rust</a></li>  </ul><p>Our <a href="/2015/interviews/">interviews</a> page is already filling up nicely with a diverse set of main track speakers. Next week we'll publish the last set of interviews. Only 10 days until FOSDEM 2015 kicks off!</p></content>     <summary type="html"><p>We are pleased to announce a fourth round of interviews with some of our main track speakers:</p>  </summary>   </entry>   <entry>     <id>tag:fosdem.org,2015-01-14:/2015/news/2015-01-14-third-fosdem-2015-speaker-interviews/</id>     <title type="html">Third set of FOSDEM 2015 speaker interviews</title>     <published>2015-01-13T23:00:00Z</published>     <updated>2015-01-13T23:00:00Z</updated>     <link rel="alternate" href="https://fosdem.org/2015/news/2015-01-14-third-fosdem-2015-speaker-interviews/"/>     <content type="html"><p>Get a sneak peek of FOSDEM 2015 in our third round of interviews with some main track speakers:</p>   <ul><li>Benjamin Berg: <a href="/2015/interviews/2015-benjamin-berg/">SDAPS: Surveying Made Easy</a></li>     <li>Gilles Van Assche, Joan Daemen and Micha\ufffd\ufffdl Peeters: <a href="/2015/interviews/2015-gilles-van-assche/">Keccak and SHA-3: code and standard updates</a></li>     <li>Jonas \ufffd\ufffdberg: <a href="/2015/interviews/2015-jonas-oeberg/">Automating Attribution: Giving credit where credit is due</a></li>     <li>Till Tantau: <a href="/2015/interviews/2015-till-tantau/">Algorithmic Graph Drawing in TikZ</a></li>     <li>Yorik van Havre: <a href="/2015/interviews/2015-yorik-van-havre/">FreeCAD: a hackable design platform</a></li> </ul><p>You can find our complete set of interviews on our <a href="/2015/interviews/">interviews</a> page, showing the diversity of our main track speakers: about languages, performance, time, typesetting, hardware, security and much more. Stay tuned for more food for thought next week.</p></content>     <summary type="html"><p>Get a sneak peek of FOSDEM 2015 in our third round of interviews with some main track speakers:</p>  </summary>   </entry> </feed>
